description.narrative: Project aims to strengthen water management practices at national and local levels in response to climate change induced water scarcity risks to local farming systems in Turkmenistan.
populated place

activity-description.narrative: At least 4,000 agri-pastoralists of the Nohur mountainous region develop and implement water harvesting and saving techniques (such as slope terracing, small rainwater collection dams, contour and stone bunds, planting pits, tillage, mulching) to improve soil moisture levels

description.narrative: populated place

activity-description.narrative: At least 8,000 farmers implement community-based well and watering point management measures, including sand fixation and introduction of drought resistant traditional grain varieties in the Karakum desert region

description.narrative: capital of a political entity
populated place

activity-description.narrative: At least 20,000 farmers in the Sakarchaga area benefit from improved irrigation services through the introduction of canal level, localized management practice.

comment.narrative:
1. Notification rate of new smear positive TB cases / number per year per 100 000 population: baseline for 2008 is 22. 2. Number and percentage of new smear-positive TB patients successfully treated (cured plus completed treatment) among the new smear-positive TB patients registered: baseline for 2008 is 83%.
Baseline source: NTP data based on 2008 smear positive case notifications and WHO estimates (‘Global Tuberculosis Control: Epidemiology, Strategy, Financing’ (WHO Report 2009), adjusted for the population size (the national figures are higher than those used by WHO). Baseline rate includes only civilian sector. Targets are set for civillian and penitentiary sectors.
Data to be available in February 2017.

Baseline source: NTP data based on 2008 smear positive case notifications and WHO estimates (‘Global Tuberculosis Control: Epidemiology, Strategy, Financing’ (WHO Report 2009), adjusted for the population size (the national figures are higher than those used by WHO). Baseline rate includes only civilian sector. Targets are set for civillian and penitentiary sectors.
Data to be available in February 2017.

description.narrative: Improving Energy Efficiency in Residential Buildings Sector of Turkmenistan

title.narrative: Annual Work Plan for 2013 (in English and Russian languages)
Annual Work Plan for 2014 in English
Annual Work Plan for 2014 in Russian language
Mid-term Evaluation of Energy Efficiency in Residential Buildings Project

description.narrative: The focus of the project is on promoting energy efficiency (EE) by improving energy management and reducing energy consumption in the residential sector in Turkmenistan. This will lead to a reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Direct beneficiaries are families living in 373 apartments in Ashgabat Other beneficiaries: - population of Turkmenistan - Ministry of Construction - Ministry of Communal Services - State Corporation “Turkmengas” - State Corporation “Oil &Gas Construction” - Ashgabat Municipality - State Building De

description.narrative: Energy - power generation
The proposed UNDP-GEF project will reduce greenhouse gas emissions by improving energy management and reducing energy consumption in the residential sector in Turkmenistan.
Reduction of direct GHG emissions from residential sector of Turkmenistan as a result of the project over 20 years, tCO2e

comment.narrative: 202,866 tCO2e by the end of the project

- Estimated direct heat energy savings of 1,484,334 kWh/yr from new pilot buildings. - Estimated avoided CO2 emissions from new buildings over 20-year lifetime of almost 12,265 tonnes.
- Estimated direct heat energy savings of 2,125,588 kWh/yr from renovated pilot buildings.
- Estimated avoided CO2 emissions from renovated buildings over 20-year lifetime of more than 10,845 tonnes. - Total estimated avoided CO2 emissions from 6 pilot buildings over 20-year lifetime of 23,110 tonnes.

description.narrative: Natural gas saved annually as a direct result of the project

comment.narrative: 5 133 thousand m3

- Estimated annual natural gas savings of about 322,788 m3 per year in 3 new pilot buildings, and also about 285,400 m3 per year in 3 pilot retrofits.
- Total estimated natural gas savings of about 608,187 m3 per year in 6 pilot buildings.

description.narrative: Co-financing leveraged for investments in energy efficient reconstruction of existing buildings and construction of new energy efficient housing stock (i.e. beyond existing building code requirements)

comment.narrative:
- The co-financing by the Government disbursed so far:
*About US $12,300 disbursed for gas meters for 22 demonstration buildings subject to energy audits and 5 demonstration buildings selected for energy management activities.
*More US $40 million disbursed for almost 270 thousand gas meters for residential buildings in the country.
*US $38 million for construction of one demonstration building - 12-story high-comfort building (114 units) including energy efficient design of the high-comfort building. Construction is completed.
*US $16.1 million for construction of second demonstration building - 12-story high-comfort building (66 units) including energy efficient design of the high-comfort building. Construction is to be completed in October 2015.
*US $3.1 million for construction of one demonstration typical 9-story building (54 apartment units). Construction is completed.
*About US $60,000 in in-kind services of the Turkmen State Building Design Institute for revision of building codes Building Thermal Engineering and Building Climatology
- Additional co-financing committed and disbursed for three demonstration projects for energy efficiency in renovation of existing buildings

description.narrative: Energy consumption in new buildings is reduced beyond current requirements
Existence and content of applicable building codes on building energy performance

comment.narrative:
- No code on whole-building energy performance. Existing codes regulate thermal resistance of building elements, but not whole-building consumption per square meter. Resultant whole-building energy consumption levels under code compliance therefore vary from building to building.
- Existing thermal engineering code adopted in 1998 contains two levels of prescriptive thermal envelope requirements, Level 1 and Level 2. Buildings consume 35-70 percent less energy under Level 2 than under Level 1, but Level 2 is implemented in practice only for elite residential buildings, not common building designs for standard housing.

- New building energy efficiency code on whole-building thermal performance and revisions of existing building codes on roofs and roofing, residential buildings, and building climatology developed and implemented.
- New code requires heat energy consumption at or beyond Level 2 for all buildings (5 to 10 percent less than Level 2 for elite residential buildings), with Level 1 compliance no longer applicable.
- Introduction of energy passport system in conjunction with adopted new and revised building codes.

- Building code “Roofs and Roofing” is approved by Ministry of Justice and ordered by Ministry of Construction and Architecture for immediate use.
- Guidance manuals accompanying building codes “Residential Buildings” and “Roofs and Roofing” are translated into Turkmen and approved by Ministry of Construction and Architecture for the use and printing.
- A draft of building code “Building Thermal Engineering” is developed and reviewed by International Consultant and sent to State Design Institute “Turkmendovlettaslama” for review.
- Training for calculation of climatic parameters needed for building code “Building Climatology” has been provided to specialists of National Committee on Hydrometeorology. Software for the calculation is installed and adjusted in the Committee.
- 80 percent of climatic parameters needed for building code “Building climatology” have been calculated by National Committee on Hydrometeorology.
- Terms of Reference for preparing a guidance manual to accompany building code “Building Thermal Engineering” is developed.
- Terms of Reference for developing a software for filling out the energy passport is prepared.
- Terms of Reference for preparing a catalogue of construction materials to accompany building code “Building Thermal Engineering” have been prepared
- 3 Russia’s standards on energy efficiency are purchased to be included to Turkmenistan’s register of standards. 2 CIS standards on energy efficiency are translated into Turkmen to be included further to Turkmenistan’s register of standards.

description.narrative: Turkmengas and other national agencies understand the potential for savings in its housing stock and have the capacity to identify and undertake investments in energy efficiency there.

- Number of energy audits
- Number of professionals trained

comment.narrative: No audits, training

- 25 energy audits carried out by project (5 planned for 2013, 10 each for 2014 and 2015.
- At least 30 professionals including Turkmengas staff trained.

- Methodology to conduct energy audits in buildings is finalised and discussed with local stakeholders. It will be sent for confirmation to relevant ministries once the provision on implementation of energy audits is completed.
- A draft of provisions (official instructions) on implementation of energy audits in residential buildings is developed.
- 22 energy audits are implemented in demo buildings in 9 cities of 5 areas of the country; reports and recommendations are prepared.
- Summary of 22 energy audits for the general public is prepared.
- About 100 local specialists in 5 administrative areas of the country are practically trained for the methodology to implement energy audits.
- Gas meters provided by State Corporation “Turkmengas” are installed in 5 buildings selected as pilots for energy management studies.
- Regular measurement of energy consumption is being conducted in 3 demonstration retrofits and 3 baseline buildings.
- Regular measurement of energy consumption (energy monitoring) is being implemented for two new pilot building (their construction is completed in the end of 2014).
- A draft of structure for energy management system for 5 pilot buildings is prepared. Energy audit of the buildings is completed, Data on regular energy consumption in the buildings is collected and analyzed.

description.narrative: Existence and volume of activity of program, run and funded by Turkmengas and/or other state agencies, on energy efficiency investment in buildings

comment.narrative: No investment program
Short- and long-term investment plan for Turkmengas and Ashgabat housing stock developed, with EE design and/or retrofit carried out in at least 25 buildings by the end of the project.

- Energy savings potential is calculated for existing building stock in key cities of Turkmenistan. Options of measures for energy efficient retrofitting of the stock are prepared. Financial assessment and scenarios of investments for energy efficient renovation of the stock have been prepared.
- A draft of National Plan on rational energy use in residential building sector has been prepared.
- Working group composed of representatives of ministries and state organizations relevant to the National plan is established and a meeting of the group is conducted.
- The assessment of energy-saving potential for existing buildings will also be used as a basis project profiles for the National Plan on Mitigation and INDC (Intended Nationally Determined Contributions on climate change) to be presented at the Conference of Parties to UNFCCC in Paris in November 2015.

description.narrative: Energy-efficient design and technologies are incorporated and visually demonstrated in new and reconstructed residential buildings
- Number of pilot buildings designed and built - Energy consumption of pilot buildings relative to similar new and existing buildings in Turkmenistan

comment.narrative: - No demonstration buildings yet built - Baseline energy consumption to be determined by calculation based on assumed standard features, as well as code requirements and statistical data on analogous existing buildings if available
New pilot buildings designed and constructed with calculated energy consumption 15 percent less than required by code, and five percent less than prevailing best practice for high-comfort buildings

- Cost estimation completed for one pilot building (12-story 66-unit), with construction in progress and due for completion by October 2015.
- Energy savings in new pilot building to be completed in October 2015:
*66-unit high-comfort - 10 percent compared to baseline
- Monitoring of energy consumption in 2 new buildings completed in the end of 2014 is in progress. For the 9-story building of the U148 series, energy savings over the first five months (November 2014 – March 2015) were measured at 227,618 kWh (~40 tonnes avoided CO2 emissions) relative to a neighboring building identical except for the absence of energy-efficiency measures, and 65,677 kWh (12 tonnes avoided CO2 emissions) beyond code requirements for new buildings. For the 12-story 114-unit high-comfort buildings, energy savings over the same five-month period were measured at 174,598 kWh beyond code requirements (about 31 tonnes avoided CO2 emissions).

description.narrative:
- Number of pilot buildings designed and renovated
- Energy consumption of pilot buildings relative to similar new and existing buildings in Turkmenistan

comment.narrative:
- No demonstration buildings yet renovated
- Baseline energy consumption to be determined by calculation based on assumed standard features, as well as code requirements and statistical data on analogous existing buildings if available
Three designs for reconstruction developed and implemented with at least 44% energy consumption reduction

- Three buildings selected as pilot retrofits are confirmed and co-financing for retrofitting is secured by the Ministry of Communal Services.
- Bilateral agreement on renovation and Letter of Agreement for retrofitting of three typical demo-buildings signed among UNDP/GEF project and client/Ministry of Communal Services.
- Energy efficient measures of three demo retrofits are completed and reviewed by International consultant on building design.
- Cost estimation completed for three pilot retrofits, with renovation in progress and due for completion by November 2015.
- Expected energy savings in three pilot retrofits:
*54-units 148-U typical 44%
*45-units UZ-500 typical 49%
*40-units 76-U typical 51%

description.narrative: Replication facilitated via development of skills, prototype designs and policies for energy-efficient buildings.
- Number of architects, engineers, and students trained with regard to enrgy efficient building design and code compliance

comment.narrative: - No training on EE building design and code compliance

- Training on energy efficient building re/construction, experience from implementing integrated building design delivered to at least 50 architects and/or engineers
- Course materials on energy efficient building design and re/construction developed and delivered to at least 30 students by the end of Q4/2014

- Practical training on implementation of energy audits in residential buildings are delivered to about 100 local specialists in 5 administrative areas of the country in the period of December 2014 - May 2015.
- Training for calculation of climatic parameters needed for building code “Building Climatology” delivered to 10 specialists of National Committee on Hydrometeorology in February 2015. Software for the calculation is installed and adjusted in the Committee.
- Bilateral agreement on revising typical programs for students and Letter of Agreement for developing and adding a section “Energy Conservation” to the typical program of four specialties in Turkmen State Architecture and Construction Institute signed among UNDP/GEF project and client/Turkmen State Architecture and Construction Institute.
- A draft of revised typical programs for students and drafts of training materials for lectures, practical and laboratory studies for the “Energy Conservation” section are prepared.
- Information on building codes being revised and practice of energy audits is delivered to teachers and students at a student conference At the Turkmen State Architecture and Construction Institute in June 2015.
- Benefits of revising building codes and energy efficient measures implemented in new pilot buildings are presented at conferences within International Construction Exhibitions in Ashgabat in August 2014 and April 2015.
- Meeting of Working Group on development of National Plan on rational use of energy resources is conducted in March 2015.
- Terms of Reference for development of guidance for designers to promote energy-efficient integrated residential building design is prepared.
- Study tour on studying energy management experience is organized to Zagreb, Croatia for 7 representatives of national project partners.

description.narrative: - Existence and content of executive reports and briefings of decision-makers on project findings, lessons learned and recommendations

comment.narrative: - No formal delivery of information or advocacy to decisionmakers on energy efficient buildings

- Executive reports and at least one high-level meeting on project findings, lessons learned and recommendations for policy makers developed and delivered to key governmental and regional policy makers by the end of the Q3/2015

Regular communication on project activities with high-level officials at Concern "Turkmengas", Ministry of Construction and Architecture, Ministry of Communal Services, Municipality of Ashgabat, Turkmen State Architecture and Construction Institute and leading design agencies.

description.narrative: Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy for Sustainable Water Management in Turkmenistan
Energy - power generation

Extent of change in energy efficiency (UNDP Integrated Results and Resources Framework indicator 1.5.2) – specifically, consumption of electricity and fossil fuels and associated emissions of CO2 from water management per hectare of irrigated land Consumption of water per hectare of irrigated land Hectares of land protected and/or reclaimed from salinization Implementation of national and sub-national plans for IWRM (UNDP Integrated Results and Resources Framework indicator 2.5.2). State and private investment in new and efficient integrated water management Number of people benefitting from new and improved water management systems

comment.narrative:
9 million GJ/year and approximately 6.9 MtCO2/year from water management, including non-agricultural uses
24 billion m3 per year of water consumption for agriculture 2 million hectares of irrigated land 69 percent of irrigated land is moderately to severely salinized; approximately 200 million hectares are severely salinized Water codex adopted in 2004, but no supporting regulations nor regional/local plans for implementation of IWRM or energy efficiency in the water sector

• Development of Green polygon is well underway to start testing and demonstration of efficient irrigation systems and practices, and with further regular monitoring to be in place in 2017 to define water savings trends and number of salinized land to be reclaimed and rehabilitated. • Assessment completed on potential reduction of GHG as a result of project interventions with clear recommendations and actions to be implemented, • ToR is drafted to undertake a comprehensive audit of diesel-based water pumps • Feasibility study initiated for construction and operation of a 14km water supply pipeline to shut down 41 diesel operated water pumps and provoke GHG reductions.

description.narrative: Extent of change in energy efficiency (UNDP Integrated Results and Resources Framework indicator 1.5.2) – specifically, consumption of electricity and fossil fuels and associated emissions of CO2 from water management per hectare of irrigated land Consumption of water per hectare of irrigated land Hectares of land protected and/or reclaimed from salinization Implementation of national and sub-national plans for IWRM (UNDP Integrated Results and Resources Framework indicator 2.5.2). State and private investment in new and efficient integrated water management Number of people benefitting from new and improved water management systems

comment.narrative:
9 million GJ/year and approximately 6.9 MtCO2/year from water management, including non-agricultural uses
24 billion m3 per year of water consumption for agriculture 2 million hectares of irrigated land 69 percent of irrigated land is moderately to severely salinized; approximately 200 million hectares are severely salinized Water codex adopted in 2004, but no supporting regulations nor regional/local plans for implementation of IWRM or energy efficiency in the water sector

• Development of Green polygon is well underway to start testing and demonstration of efficient irrigation systems and practices, and with further regular monitoring to be in place in 2017 to define water savings trends and number of salinized land to be reclaimed and rehabilitated. • Assessment completed on potential reduction of GHG as a result of project interventions with clear recommendations and actions to be implemented, • ToR is drafted to undertake a comprehensive audit of diesel-based water pumps • Feasibility study initiated for construction and operation of a 14km water supply pipeline to shut down 41 diesel operated water pumps and provoke GHG reductions.
